quotes.topic_title: Wizard-of-Oz tests for Gmail tabbed inbox
quotes.text: You fake it, you do a fake door test, you do a smoke test, Wizard of Oz tests.
quotes.speaker: Itamar Gilad
quotes.context: A concise, actionable methodology list for validating product value before building the real system.

quotes.topic_title: Wizard-of-Oz tests for Gmail tabbed inbox
quotes.text: one of the first early versions was actually we showed the tabbed inbox working to people. But it wasn't really Gmail, it was just a facade of HTML and behind the scenes and according to the permissions that the users gave us some of us moved just the subject and the sender into the right place.
quotes.speaker: Itamar Gilad
quotes.context: A concrete Wizard-of-Oz implementation example showing how to simulate a complex feature with a lightweight manual backend.

quotes.topic_title: Wizard-of-Oz tests for Gmail tabbed inbox
quotes.text: So initially the interviewer kind of distracted them and then showed them their inbox and then the top 50 messages were sorted to the right place more or less if we got it right.
quotes.speaker: Itamar Gilad
quotes.context: A specific testing tactic (manual sorting of the top 50 messages) that makes the prototype feel real enough to evaluate user reaction.

quotes.topic_title: Wizard-of-Oz tests for Gmail tabbed inbox
quotes.text: And people were like, "Wow, this is actually very cool." But it gave us some evidence to go and say, "Hey, we should try and build this thing."
quotes.speaker: Itamar Gilad
quotes.context: Illustrates how early qualitative feedback from a fake prototype can provide evidence to justify investing in building the real feature.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Itamar, has an important perspective on why and also how you can push your team and organization from an opinion-based decision-making process to a more evidence guided approach.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Captures the core actionable shift from opinion-driven decisions to an evidence-guided operating model.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: In our conversation, Itamar, shares a number of very practical and handy frameworks that do just that including the confidence meter, metrics trees, GIST and the GIST board, plus his take on how people often misuse ICE for prioritizing ideas.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Names concrete frameworks and a common prioritization pitfall practitioners can immediately explore and apply.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Half of all men will have cancer at some point in their lives, as will one third of women.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A striking data point used to motivate proactive screening and risk-aware decision-making.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Half of all of them will detect it late.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights the counterintuitive reality that detection timing is a major problem, reinforcing the value of early checks.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: According to the American Cancer Society, early cancer detection has an 80% survival rate compared to less than 20% for late stage cancer.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: A stark data point that makes the case for prioritizing early detection and proactive screening.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: The Ezra, team has helped 13% of their customers identify potential cancer early and 50% of them identify other clinically significant issues such as aneurysms, disc herniations, which may be is what I have or fatty liver disease.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: Quantifies the practical yield of full-body screening beyond cancer, highlighting unexpected but actionable findings.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Luckily, I had what they called an unremarkable screening which means they didn't find anything cancerous. But they did find some issues in my back which I'm getting checked out at a physical next month probably because I spend so much time sitting in front of a computer.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: A concrete example of using screening results to trigger follow-up care for non-cancer issues that affect day-to-day health.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Over 5,000 fast-growing companies use Vanta to automate up to 90% of the work involved with SOC 2 and these other frameworks.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: A specific adoption and efficiency claim that suggests a scalable approach to reducing compliance workload via automation.

quotes.topic_title: Google+ integration: opinion-based product failure
quotes.text: It turned out people actually didn't need another social network, people didn't love it, people didn't use it.
quotes.speaker: Itamar Gilad
quotes.context: A blunt reminder to validate real user demand rather than assuming market need based on competitive pressure.

quotes.topic_title: Google+ integration: opinion-based product failure
quotes.text: So putting aside all the tremendous waste that went into this, all the millions of person hours and personal weeks.
quotes.speaker: Itamar Gilad
quotes.context: Highlights the scale of cost when big bets are made without sufficient evidence, underscoring the importance of early kill criteria.

quotes.topic_title: Google+ integration: opinion-based product failure
quotes.text: In hindsight, not only did Google bet on the wrong thing it missed much easier opportunities.
quotes.speaker: Itamar Gilad
quotes.context: Points to opportunity cost as a key product strategy lens: wrong big bets can crowd out simpler, higher-leverage moves.

quotes.topic_title: Google+ integration: opinion-based product failure
quotes.text: So Google missed the opportunity of social mobile apps like WhatsApp, like Snapchat, etc and for me this story kind of was the epitome of what I call today, opinion-based development.
quotes.speaker: Itamar Gilad
quotes.context: Names a failure mode (“opinion-based development”) and ties it to concrete missed-market examples practitioners can watch for.

quotes.topic_title: Google+ integration: opinion-based product failure
quotes.text: We come up with an idea, we believe in it, all the indications show it's good.
quotes.speaker: Itamar Gilad
quotes.context: Captures how teams can over-trust internal conviction and weak signals, motivating more rigorous evidence standards before scaling.

quotes.topic_title: Scale and organizational cost of Google+
quotes.text: So there was a tremendous earthquake inside Google to create the Google+ team, teams and the entire divisions were kind of thrown apart and reformatted and I think at its peak it was about 1000 people inside-
quotes.speaker: Itamar Gilad
quotes.context: A vivid example of the organizational disruption and scale that can result from a top-down product bet.

quotes.topic_title: Scale and organizational cost of Google+
quotes.text: It was a division the size of Android and Docs and a really sizable thing, they're under their own buildings.
quotes.speaker: Itamar Gilad
quotes.context: Quantifies the opportunity cost by comparing Google+ to other major divisions, underscoring how big bets can consume massive resources.

quotes.topic_title: Scale and organizational cost of Google+
quotes.text: It's taken from the playbook of Steve Jobs, create this whole secretive project inside and just run like hell.
quotes.speaker: Itamar Gilad
quotes.context: Highlights a recognizable (and risky) execution model—secretive, high-speed internal skunkworks—that practitioners can evaluate before copying.

quotes.topic_title: Scale and organizational cost of Google+
quotes.text: But at the end of the day, neither Google's advertising revenue was affected, neither was Facebook affected.
quotes.speaker: Itamar Gilad
quotes.context: A counterintuitive outcome: even a massive competitive response may not move the core business metrics on either side.

quotes.topic_title: Scale and organizational cost of Google+
quotes.text: So it turned out this idea was not that necessary after all.
quotes.speaker: Itamar Gilad
quotes.context: A reminder to validate necessity early—big, fear-driven initiatives can be unnecessary despite intense competitive pressure.

quotes.topic_title: Tabbed inbox success through evidence-guided iteration
quotes.text: So essentially it put a high premium on focusing on customers, coming up with a lot of ideas on looking at the data, looking at how these ideas actually worked out.
quotes.speaker: Itamar Gilad
quotes.context: Defines the core operating model of an evidence-guided company: customer focus + many ideas + data-driven evaluation.

quotes.topic_title: Tabbed inbox success through evidence-guided iteration
quotes.text: So fail fast is a very famous paradigm and so you had to kill your project or pivot it seriously if it didn't work out
quotes.speaker: Itamar Gilad
quotes.context: Actionable guidance on enforcing real consequences from learning—kill or pivot based on results.

quotes.topic_title: Tabbed inbox success through evidence-guided iteration
quotes.text: So it was kind of the reverse of Google+, it started as a very small idea that no one believed in and we started looking what's behind the city? What's the goal? What's the problem actually we're trying to solve?
quotes.speaker: Itamar Gilad
quotes.context: A practical problem-first framing that shows how to rescue a doubted idea by clarifying goal and user problem.

quotes.topic_title: Tabbed inbox success through evidence-guided iteration
quotes.text: So that sent us, kind of me and my team into researching these users into establishing a goal that was much more user-centric and then thinking of other ideas.
quotes.speaker: Itamar Gilad
quotes.context: Shows the iterative move from opinion to user research, user-centric goals, and generating alternative solutions.

quotes.topic_title: Tabbed inbox success through evidence-guided iteration
quotes.text: But there's about 85% of the population, 85 to 88% that absolutely love it and today Gmail has about 1.8 billion active users according to Gmail.
quotes.speaker: Itamar Gilad
quotes.context: Concrete data point illustrating that a feature that seems “stupid” to power users can be beloved by the majority at massive scale.

quotes.topic_title: Book pitch: moving organizations to evidence-guided
quotes.text: So this is a book for people like us, product people who want to bring evidence guided thinking or modern product management if you like into their organizations.
quotes.speaker: Itamar Gilad
quotes.context: Defines the target audience and the practical goal: helping product practitioners introduce evidence-guided thinking inside real organizations.

quotes.topic_title: Book pitch: moving organizations to evidence-guided
quotes.text: There's a lot of challenges, it's not simple, we all read the books, we all know the theory, we all know some parts of the system.
quotes.speaker: Itamar Gilad
quotes.context: Highlights the common gap between knowing modern product theory and being able to implement it amid organizational constraints.

quotes.topic_title: Book pitch: moving organizations to evidence-guided
quotes.text: It tries to give you a system how to do that, it's a meta framework that kind of helps you lift your organization in the direction of evidence guidance if that's what you want to do.
quotes.speaker: Itamar Gilad
quotes.context: Introduces the core methodology: a meta-framework designed to move an organization toward evidence-guided decision-making.

quotes.topic_title: Book pitch: moving organizations to evidence-guided
quotes.text: In the first example of Google+, basically it came top down, "Hey, we need to build a social network, go build it."
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Provides a concrete example of opinion-led/top-down product direction that evidence-guided approaches aim to address.

quotes.topic_title: Founders, vision, and the myth of pure intuition
quotes.text: However, it's not about shutting them down it's about looking at them critically.
quotes.speaker: Itamar Gilad
quotes.context: A practical stance for handling founder-led ideas: create space for vision, but require critical evaluation rather than deference or dismissal.

quotes.topic_title: Founders, vision, and the myth of pure intuition
quotes.text: You need to create the environment in the organization where the leader comes and says, "You know what? I talked to these three customers, I figured it out. Here's what we need to do in the next five years." And you need to ask, "Where's your evidence?"
quotes.speaker: Itamar Gilad
quotes.context: A concrete, repeatable method for evidence-guiding executive intuition: institutionalize the norm of asking for evidence even when leaders sound confident.

quotes.topic_title: Founders, vision, and the myth of pure intuition
quotes.text: Steve Jobs, he just brainstorm in his kitchen the iPhone and then just told the team to build it. That's the story Steve Jobs, told but it's not the real story at all.
quotes.speaker: Itamar Gilad
quotes.context: Challenges the common myth of pure founder intuition, reframing iconic product creation as more complex than a single visionary moment.

quotes.topic_title: Founders, vision, and the myth of pure intuition
quotes.text: Now we know what actually happened and the iPhone has actually a story of discovery, of trial and error, multiple projects to do it, multitouch with phones, most of them failed.
quotes.speaker: Itamar Gilad
quotes.context: A specific example that reinforces an evidence-and-iteration model: even legendary successes emerged through experiments and failures.

quotes.topic_title: Founders, vision, and the myth of pure intuition
quotes.text: He was actually against it for a while but over time as he saw the evidence, as he saw what this thing can do, as he saw the demos he was able to piece together something that was very useful.
quotes.speaker: Itamar Gilad
quotes.context: Counterintuitive insight that even visionary leaders can change their minds based on evidence, underscoring the value of demos and learning loops.

quotes.topic_title: How to push back with evidence in organizations
quotes.text: I think what I would change is not have this discussion based on opinions, because when you have the discussion you come with your own opinions usually the most senior person's opinions will win.
quotes.speaker: Itamar Gilad
quotes.context: Highlights why opinion-based debates tend to default to hierarchy, motivating a shift to evidence-driven decision-making.

quotes.topic_title: How to push back with evidence in organizations
quotes.text: If we had come with hard data and we said, "Listen, things are not actually panning out the way you guys are expecting. What can we do? Should we continue? Should we pivot this?" I think the discussion would've done better.
quotes.speaker: Itamar Gilad
quotes.context: Provides a concrete script for reframing executive discussions around data and explicit decision options (continue vs. pivot).

quotes.topic_title: How to push back with evidence in organizations
quotes.text: But it's just as a general trend, I find that evidence is very empowering for us smaller people in the organization or mid-level managers to be empowered to challenge the opinions.
quotes.speaker: Itamar Gilad
quotes.context: Offers a practical mental model: evidence as a power equalizer for mid-level leaders pushing back on senior viewpoints.

quotes.topic_title: How to push back with evidence in organizations
quotes.text: I think if you come with data, if you run a secret experiment and you come back and you show them you usually get one of two results.
quotes.speaker: Itamar Gilad
quotes.context: Introduces a tactical approach (run an experiment) and a clear expectation-setting framework for how leadership may respond.

quotes.topic_title: How to push back with evidence in organizations
quotes.text: Either they get extremely mad at you and they tell you to get back to work and to do what you were told and in that case, probably you need to start polishing your resume and look for another place either inside the organization or outside it because that person is not being reasonable to be honest.
quotes.speaker: Itamar Gilad
quotes.context: Gives blunt, actionable guidance on what a hostile reaction to evidence signals about culture fit and career risk.

quotes.topic_title: Signs your company isn’t truly evidence-guided
quotes.text: I think there's a few telltale signs that I look for, first the goals are very unclear. Either there are many or they're very kind of obscure and vague or they are about output, there's misalignment.
quotes.speaker: Itamar Gilad
quotes.context: A practical diagnostic: unclear, output-focused, or misaligned goals are an early warning sign you’re not truly evidence-guided.

quotes.topic_title: Signs your company isn’t truly evidence-guided
quotes.text: Missing metrics or just using revenue and business metric but there's no user facing metrics.
quotes.speaker: Itamar Gilad
quotes.context: Highlights a common measurement gap—without user-facing metrics, “data-driven” decisions can be misleading.

quotes.topic_title: Signs your company isn’t truly evidence-guided
quotes.text: Creating the perfect roadmap which really can consume a lot of time of the top management and PMs, etc.
quotes.speaker: Itamar Gilad
quotes.context: A counterintuitive red flag: heavy roadmap planning can substitute for evidence and learning.

quotes.topic_title: Signs your company isn’t truly evidence-guided
quotes.text: Then as you go down you see there's not a lot of experimentation and if there is experimentation there's not a lot of learning and finally another telltale sign is that the team is disengaged.
quotes.speaker: Itamar Gilad
quotes.context: Connects weak experiment/learning loops to team disengagement—useful for diagnosing systemic issues beyond process.

quotes.topic_title: Signs your company isn’t truly evidence-guided
quotes.text: It's usually something that you can fix by adopting a more evidence guided system.
quotes.speaker: Itamar Gilad
quotes.context: A direct prescription: shifting to an evidence-guided system is positioned as the lever to address these symptoms.

quotes.topic_title: GIST model overview: Goals, Ideas, Steps, Tasks
quotes.text: So this is the GIST model, goals, ideas, steps and tasks, and essentially it's tries to break the change which is a really big change for a lot of companies into four slightly more manageable parts.
quotes.speaker: Itamar Gilad
quotes.context: Defines the core GIST framework as a way to make organizational change toward evidence-guided product development more tractable.

quotes.topic_title: GIST model overview: Goals, Ideas, Steps, Tasks
quotes.text: goals are about defining what we're trying to achieve, ideas are hypothetical ways to achieve the goals, steps are ways to implement the idea and validate it at the same time. So essentially build, measure learn loops and tasks are the things we manage in Kanban and Jira and all these good tools.
quotes.speaker: Itamar Gilad
quotes.context: Provides an actionable mapping from outcomes to hypotheses to validation loops to execution tooling, clarifying what belongs at each layer.

quotes.topic_title: GIST model overview: Goals, Ideas, Steps, Tasks
quotes.text: GIST is not a brand new invention. It's a meta framework that puts in place a lot of existing methodologies.
quotes.speaker: Itamar Gilad
quotes.context: Positions GIST as an integrative mental model that unifies familiar practices rather than adding yet another new process.

quotes.topic_title: GIST model overview: Goals, Ideas, Steps, Tasks
quotes.text: The principles behind them, the frameworks or models that implement the principles and then process and the process honestly is the most brittle part and the one that you would need to change and adapt to your company.
quotes.speaker: Itamar Gilad
quotes.context: Actionable guidance on what to standardize vs. tailor: keep principles stable, but expect to adapt process to your context.

quotes.topic_title: GIST model overview: Goals, Ideas, Steps, Tasks
quotes.text: In many companies the strategy is just a roadmap on steroids, it's small plan and execute just on a grand scale
quotes.speaker: Itamar Gilad
quotes.context: Contrarian critique that challenges conventional “strategy” practices that are really just scaled-up planning without evidence-guided learning.

quotes.topic_title: Goals layer: value exchange, North Star, metrics trees
quotes.text: So when people say I have goals, usually they take the goals layer and use it as a planning session. They talk about what shall we build by when, what are the resources? And that's actually not goals at all, that's planning work.
quotes.speaker: Itamar Gilad
quotes.context: Challenges the common mistake of confusing goal-setting with delivery planning, clarifying what “goals” should and shouldn’t contain.

quotes.topic_title: Goals layer: value exchange, North Star, metrics trees
quotes.text: Where basically the organization is trying to deliver as much value as it can to the market and to capture as much value back, and by creating a feedback loop between these two you are actually able to grow very fast.
quotes.speaker: Itamar Gilad
quotes.context: Introduces the “value exchange loop” as a simple, organization-wide model for defining goals around value delivered and value captured.

quotes.topic_title: Goals layer: value exchange, North Star, metrics trees
quotes.text: But it's not what I call the North Star metric, the North Star metric measures how much value we create for the market.
quotes.speaker: Itamar Gilad
quotes.context: Draws a sharp distinction between “most important metric” and a true North Star metric anchored specifically in user value creation.

quotes.topic_title: Goals layer: value exchange, North Star, metrics trees
quotes.text: So there's a metric three for the North Star metric and there's the metric three for the top KPI, the top business metric which you see here on the left side in blue and usually they overlap. So you might find in the middle some metrics that are super, super important because moving them actually moves the needle on everything else.
quotes.speaker: Itamar Gilad
quotes.context: Explains metrics trees as a way to connect user-value metrics and business KPIs, revealing shared “middle” levers with outsized impact.

quotes.topic_title: Goals layer: value exchange, North Star, metrics trees
quotes.text: But if you start with a metrics tree, you can try to arrange the topology around goals and sometimes you need to readjust.
quotes.speaker: Itamar Gilad
quotes.context: Offers a practical method for org design: derive team topology from metric ownership and goal structure rather than software or hierarchy.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Census had a 10x increase in pipeline with the LinkedIn startup team, for Webflow after ramping up on LinkedIn in Q4 they had the highest marketing source revenue quarter to date.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Concrete B2B case studies showing measurable outcomes from scaling LinkedIn Ads.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: With LinkedIn Ads, you'll have direct access to and can build relationships with decision makers including 950 million members, 180 million senior execs and over 10 million C-level executives.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A scale-and-targeting data point that supports LinkedIn as a decision-maker-heavy channel for B2B.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: We're flooded with ideas, and what usually happens inside organization is some sort of battle of opinions or some sort of politics sometimes or highest paid person's opinion.
quotes.speaker: Itamar Gilad
quotes.context: Highlights a common failure mode in prioritization that an “ideas layer” is meant to prevent.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: What doesn't happen is very rational, logical decisions these are the best ideas, because it's really, really hard to predict honestly.
quotes.speaker: Itamar Gilad
quotes.context: Challenges the assumption that teams can reliably pick “best ideas” upfront, motivating evidence-guided methods.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: It's almost impossible to say this idea is going to be the best, but we do say this because we have cognitive biases that kind of convince us that this idea is far superior to anything else and it's definitely the right choice.
quotes.speaker: Itamar Gilad
quotes.context: A memorable warning about overconfidence and bias in idea selection, reinforcing the need for structured evaluation.

quotes.topic_title: Ideas layer: ICE prioritization and confidence scoring
quotes.text: In order to avoid this, what we want to do is to evaluate the ideas in a much more objective and consistent and transparent way. In the book I suggest using ICE, impact, confidence and ease.
quotes.speaker: Itamar Gilad
quotes.context: Introduces ICE as a practical, repeatable framework to reduce politics/HiPPO-driven prioritization.

quotes.topic_title: Ideas layer: ICE prioritization and confidence scoring
quotes.text: The impact tries to assess how much impact it'll have on the goals and that's why it's so important that we have very clear goals and not many.
quotes.speaker: Itamar Gilad
quotes.context: Connects prioritization quality directly to having a small set of clear goals/metrics to score against.

quotes.topic_title: Ideas layer: ICE prioritization and confidence scoring
quotes.text: But then there's the third element which is confidence, which tries to assess how sure are we or should we be about our first guesstimates about the impact and the ease.
quotes.speaker: Itamar Gilad
quotes.context: Defines confidence as a separate score to reflect evidence strength behind impact/effort estimates.

quotes.topic_title: Ideas layer: ICE prioritization and confidence scoring
quotes.text: So when you come to estimate impact you will realize it's the hardest part.
quotes.speaker: Itamar Gilad
quotes.context: Highlights the key bottleneck in prioritization: impact estimation is inherently the most uncertain.

quotes.topic_title: Ideas layer: ICE prioritization and confidence scoring
quotes.text: What happens is that people tend to just go with gut instinct and then give themselves a high confidence. They say it's an eight and I'm pretty convinced, so it's eight for confidence and I found this a bit disturbing because it kind of subverts the whole system.
quotes.speaker: Itamar Gilad
quotes.context: Warns that teams often misuse confidence scoring by equating conviction with evidence, undermining ICE.

quotes.topic_title: Confidence meter: evidence ladder and testing tradeoffs
quotes.text: So you can also tie your investment into the idea based on the level of confidence you had found essentially, so early on you want to do the cheap stuff just to gain more confidence and then you can go and invest more.
quotes.speaker: Itamar Gilad
quotes.context: Actionable guidance for sizing investment based on evidence strength, encouraging low-cost learning before big bets.

quotes.topic_title: Confidence meter: evidence ladder and testing tradeoffs
quotes.text: So part of the trick is also knowing when to stop, not just trying to force your way all the way up when you don't have to.
quotes.speaker: Itamar Gilad
quotes.context: A practical stopping rule: don’t over-test when risk is low or the decision doesn’t warrant more rigor.

quotes.topic_title: Confidence meter: evidence ladder and testing tradeoffs
quotes.text: It never works honestly, you should not assume that your competitor actually knows what they're doing anymore than you do.
quotes.speaker: Itamar Gilad
quotes.context: Contrarian warning against treating competitor behavior as validation, pushing teams to seek real evidence instead.

quotes.topic_title: Confidence meter: evidence ladder and testing tradeoffs
quotes.text: The metric is not how fast can we get the bits into production, when there's a lot of uncertainty and we all face uncertainty and startup especially. It's not about getting the bits to production, it's about getting the right bits to production. It's about creating the outcomes that you need, the impact, and so it's about time to outcomes
quotes.speaker: Itamar Gilad
quotes.context: Reframes delivery speed into an outcomes-focused metric (“time to outcomes”) for high-uncertainty environments.

quotes.topic_title: Confidence meter: evidence ladder and testing tradeoffs
quotes.text: Plus it is a fallacy that if you learn you don't build, good teams know how to do both at the same time
quotes.speaker: Itamar Gilad
quotes.context: Challenges the common discovery-vs-delivery tradeoff by asserting strong teams can learn and ship in parallel.
